message.content:
Create a compatibility detection module for splice-cep that:

1. Detects the runtime environment (Apple Silicon vs Intel, macOS version, Premiere Pro version)
2. Logs environment info on extension startup
3. Provides feature detection utilities instead of hardware detection
4. Adds proper error handling with fallbacks for different environments

Create the file at splice-cep/panel/js/compatibility.js and integrate it into the main extension initialization.

content.text: Now let me read the main.js file to understand the extension initialization pattern and the CSInterface.js to understand how the CEP environment works.
Now let me read the index.html to see how scripts are loaded and understand the extension structure better.

file.content:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<ExtensionManifest xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
                   ExtensionBundleId="com.splice.panel"
                   ExtensionBundleVersion="6.0.8"
                   Version="11.0">

    <ExtensionList>
        <Extension Id="com.splice.panel.main" Version="6.0.8"/>
    </ExtensionList>

    <ExecutionEnvironment>
        <HostList>
            <!-- PP 2022 (v22.x), PP 2023 (v23.x), PP 2024 (v24.x), PP 2025 (v25.x) -->
            <Host Name="PPRO" Version="[22.0,99.9]"/>
        </HostList>
        <LocaleList>
            <Locale Code="All"/>
        </LocaleList>
        <RequiredRuntimeList>
            <!-- CEP 11 supports PP 2022-2025 -->
            <RequiredRuntime Name="CSXS" Version="11.0"/>
        </RequiredRuntimeList>
    </ExecutionEnvironment>

    <DispatchInfoList>
        <Extension Id="com.splice.panel.main">
            <DispatchInfo>
                <Resources>
                    <MainPath>./panel/index.html</MainPath>
                    <ScriptPath>./jsx/hostScript.jsx</ScriptPath>
                    <CEFCommandLine>
                        <Parameter>--allow-file-access</Parameter>
                        <Parameter>--allow-file-access-from-files</Parameter>
                        <Parameter>--enable-nodejs</Parameter>
                        <Parameter>--mixed-context</Parameter>
                    </CEFCommandLine>
                </Resources>
                <AccessList>
                    <URLAccess>
                        <URL>https://splice-api-production.up.railway.app</URL>
                        <URL>https://spliceclips.com</URL>
                        <URL>https://splice.video</URL>
                    </URLAccess>
                </AccessList>
                <Lifecycle>
                    <AutoVisible>true</AutoVisible>
                </Lifecycle>
                <UI>
                    <Type>Panel</Type>
                    <Menu>SPLICE - AI Video Editor</Menu>
                    <Geometry>
                        <Size>
                            <Height>800</Height>
                            <Width>400</Width>
                        </Size>
                        <MinSize>
                            <Height>400</Height>
                            <Width>300</Width>
                        </MinSize>
                        <MaxSize>
                            <Height>2000</Height>
                            <Width>800</Width>
                        </MaxSize>
                    </Geometry>
                    <Icons>
                        <Icon Type="Normal">./panel/icons/icon-light.png</Icon>
                        <Icon Type="DarkNormal">./panel/icons/icon-dark.png</Icon>
                    </Icons>
                </UI>
            </DispatchInfo>
        </Extension>
    </DispatchInfoList>
</ExtensionManifest>

content.text: Now I have a complete understanding of the structure. I will create the compatibility detection module. Let me create the file and then integrate it into the HTML.

Now I need to integrate the compatibility module into the main extension by adding it to the index.html. The script should be loaded early, right after browser-simulation.js and CSInterface.js but before config.js.

input.old_string:
<!-- Scripts -->
    <!-- Browser simulation MUST load first to mock window.__adobe_cep__ before CSInterface checks for it -->
    <script src="js/browser-simulation.js"></script>
    <script src="js/CSInterface.js"></script>
    <script src="js/config.js"></script>
input.new_string:
<!-- Scripts -->
    <!-- Browser simulation MUST load first to mock window.__adobe_cep__ before CSInterface checks for it -->
    <script src="js/browser-simulation.js"></script>
    <script src="js/CSInterface.js"></script>
    <script src="js/compatibility.js"></script>
    <script src="js/config.js"></script>

content.text: Now let me also integrate the compatibility module into the main.js initialization sequence to detect Premiere Pro features after the JSX bridge is ready. I will add a call to detect Premiere features after the JSX initialization.

lines: +    // Detect Premiere Pro features after JSX is ready
+            console.warn('[SPLICE] Failed to detect Premiere features:', e.message);
// Initialize sequence event listeners for real-time state updates

content.text: Now let me also add the compatibility information to the debug diagnostics in main.js to make it more useful for troubleshooting.
Now let me also add a compatibility check to the diagnostics to show feature availability and any compatibility issues.
Let me add a compatibility check section to the diagnostics, right after the QE DOM check.

lines: addDiagnosticLog('✗ QE DOM check FAILED: ' + e.message);
